title: brit marbella surfboard man
story: The -year-old was picked up by coastguards off the Costa del Sol resort of Marbella yesterday afternoon.Coastguards who rescued him released the snap today showing him with a lejacket on over a white shirt with his sleeves rolled up his arms.A spokesman for Spanish Coastguards said in a tweet: Salvamar Vega yesterday rescued and took to Estepona a man discovered by a yacht  miles south-west of Marbella.“He was adrt on a surfboard. The man who was rescued said he had been at sea for three days after falling from a ship.”Crew members on a yacht called Estelar who alerted rescuers after spotting him said he was fully dressed and told them he had spent several days at sea after falling off a boat.Local reports late last night described the man as British and the vessel as a cruise ship, which has yet to be identied.He is said to have told coastguards sent to his rescue that the accident had happened three days earlier.Coastguard vessel Salvamar Vega took him to Estepona Port so a waiting ambulance could take him to a local health centre to be treated for hypothermia.His exact whereabouts last night was unknown.Police, who could not be reached for comment, are expected to question him about his ordeal as soon as he is better.The rescue, which is starting to be reported in Spanish press, has fuelled a wave of speculation about how the mystery man ended up on a surfboard.One social media user said: “I’m intrigued about this story, because finding a surfboard while you’re lost at sea would be even stranger than falling off a boat with the surfboard.”Another added: “What’s the story, that they threw the surfboard to him when he fell instead of rescuing him ”In , a British air hostess survived  hours floating at sea reportedly jumped off the cruise ship after a drunken row with her boyfriend.Kay, an air hostess, plunged into the sea from the cruise ship as it sailed to Venice from the port of Vargarola near Pula, Croatia.The -year-old then spent  hours floating at sea - later crediting her yoga training with keeping her fit enough to survive.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: business owners relatives quarter bosses recruitment
story: The study of  small business owners found that of the  per cent who took on a family member,  per cent hired their partner, while  per cent recruited a sibling.And one in  even asked for help from their in-laws.Almost halfemployed relatives during lockdown because they needed extra help, while  per cent felt their loved ones had the skills they were looking for.Other reasons included the family member wanting to gain work experience or because they were struggling to find work after finishing education during the pandemic.The research, commissioned by Funding Circle, found the family employment typically lasted seven weeks, but  per cent still have their relative working for them.And while  per cent are considering taking them on full time following this experience,  per cent would look at hiring more relatives in the future.It also emerged that as a result of this, more than a fth would like to see more traditional family businesses making a comeback.Lisa Jacobs, Funding Circles UK managing director, said: Family sits at the heart of many successful small businesses.One of the silver linings of this crisis might be a revival of the traditional family business, with title: leo mckinstry schools reopening militant teaching unions
story: After the long summer holidays, it signies hope at the chance of fresh beginnings and excitement at the prospect of change.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesNext week, the new term will have greater meaning than ever for pupils, professionals and parents. At last, after an unprecedented lockdown of six months, all schools are due to re-open, representing a giant leap back towards normality. But the damage caused by the Coronavirus disruption has been severe.Many parents have been prevented from ing to work. Young people’s education has been badly undermined, especially because the quality of online learning has been so uneven. One study found that a fth of pupils had less than an hour’s instruction a day. Moreover, social activities and friendships – which are a vital part of growing up – have been heavily restricted.The exam chaos over the last fortnight was a fitting symbol of the vacuum created by the absence of proper schooling. No advanced society canwhen a vital sector like education is temporarily paralysed. That is why it is so important that the Government succeeds in its goal of seeing a fullto the classroom. As Boris Johnson put it at the weekend, “it is vital for pupils’ education. It is vital for their welfare. It’s vital for their physical and, indeed, mental well-being.”Given the Government’s mixed record on its management of the Covid crisis, this will be a big test. From the inadequate supply of protective gear to the botched imposition of quarantine rules, Ministers have got it badly wrong at times. They cannot afford another fiasco next week.But to do that, they will have to curtail the influence of militant teaching unions, which thrive in a climate of scare-mongering and grievance. Full of negativity, these hardened left-wing operators turn every pebble of dficulty into a giant boulder of obstruction. They are the abominable no men and women, the ultimate “can’t do” brigade.To overcome the unions’ capacity for trouble-making, reassurances about safety will be absolutely crucial. Most teachers are keen to go back to work, but they want to know schools will not be dangerous environments. That is why the recent upbeat advice from medical experts has been so welcome. It is clear from the Covid experience around the world that not only are children less likely to transmit the disease than any other group, but also that schools are safer than most other workplaces. Yesterday, the Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jenny Harries pointed out that a child is more likely to be involved in a traffic accident or die from flu than to be harmed by Coronavirus.That message was also spelt out by her boss Chris Whitty, who said on Sunday that the damage to health caused by a continued schools lockdown is potentially greater than the impact of Covid. “The balance of risk is very strongly in favour of children going to school,” he declared, adding the chances of catching the disease “are incredibly small.” In fact, there is now hard evidence to prove this. Although the vast majority of schools were closed since March, over one million pupils – such as the children of essential workers – went back to the classroom in June. Yet a comprehensive study by Public Health England showed that in the subsequent weeks until the end of term, just  children and  staff tested positive for Covid- – and nearly all these infections occurred outside the school. There were hardly any cases of children passing on the disease to each other, or to their teachers. Other research from around the world has come to the same conclusion.But none of this seems to matter to the teaching unions, eager to exploit anxiety in pursuit of their anti-Tory agenda. These are the organisations which for decades have blocked every major reform of the education system and have defended every outdated working practice. With depressing inevitability, they have continually put their own narrow interests before the wider needs of pupils. They want the respect due to trained professionals but they frequently display the rebellious spirit of the permanent agitators. “Strike action is a very powerful tool,” said Amanda Martin, the President of the ,-strong National Education Unionin an interview with the Communist Morning Star newspaper in , adding, “I’ve run demos and rallies and worked with trade councils to bring everyone out and that’s brilliant.”Led by the NEU, the unions have brought the same attitude to the Coronavirus crisis. Instead of looking for solutions, they have endlessly exaggerated problems. One Whitehall insider says of Dr Mary Bousted, the £,-a-year joint general secretary of the NEU, “it’s all about the union, to hell with the teachers who want to get back into the classroom – let alone the children.” A left-wing radical, Bousted jokes that the word “strike” was one of the first she learnt as a child. Hers is not the voice of co-operation and enterprise, so it is hardly surprising that the Government has struggled to get schools reopened.In June, a planned majorwas thwarted by the unions, dealing a severe blow to Gavin Williamson’s credibility. One left-wing website gushed that the continued shutdown was due “to the hard work of NEU branch secretaries and rank and file militants galvanising the members.” In the months since, an alliance of unions – including Bousted’s NEU and Unite led by the notorious Merseyside militant Len McCluskey – have fought a y battle against a swt re-opening. Central to this effort at sabotage was a vast -point checklist of detailed questions which the Department for Education was told it had to answer. Dubbed by critics “a wreckers’ charter”, the list included queries such as “will lidded bins with double bagging be available in every classroom”, “will dedicated space be available for any breastfeeding women to express milk” and “has behaviour policy been reviewed to acknowledge the increased level of trauma and anxiety experienced by pupils ” Some Tories complained that the union was playing politics. Robert Halfon, the chairman of the Education Select Committee was amazed at the warped priorities: “It is incredible that not one of these nit-picking questions asks the most important thing of all – what’s best for the kids ”Even as September approaches, the whining and resistance has not ceased. “The unions need to stand firm and protect their members,” argues socialist teacher Martin Powell-Davies. In the latest ruse, the public sector outfit UNISON not only wants its members to wear masks in the classroom – something for which there is no scientic evidence of any need – but also to have extra funding for deep cleaning. “Schools need more money to pay for specially trained cleaners, rather than relying on other staff who are busy enough already,” says Jon Richards, UNISON’s head of education. The moan about over-stretched budgets is a favourite of the union movement but it is an empty accusation. The Government is pouring an extra £. billion into education, while this summer it was announced that teachers’ pay is to go up by an average of . per cent, a bigger increase than any other public sector workers received.But that did nothing to stop the combination of whingeing and shroud-waving. The mentality of the hardliners was embodied in a recent statement from the NEU’s far left “Education Solidarity Network” which set out a series of demands to “make sure safety comes first.” Among them were: “smaller class sizes to allow adequate physical distancing” arrangements “for rotas and home learning to be produced in consultation with parents” “local risk assessments to include staggered outdoor breaks, sanitising, provision of transparent coverings to enable access to lip reading and facial expression” and “weekly onsite testing of staff”. Above all, the Network called for extra funding “to implement these measures.” If there were any question of a risk to safety, the union should “prepare for a national strike ballot.”That was so typical. This lot seem to feel more comfortable on the picket line than in the classroom. The Solidary Network might be seen as extreme, but its carping outlook runs right through the unionYesterday, the NEU’s joint general secretary was bleating on the airwaves about the risks of new Covid spikes: “Staff, parents and pupils are being sorely let down by the government because of a lack of a Plan B and of ensuring robust track and trace is in place throughout the country. We believe the Government is negligent in the extreme.” The charge of negligence might be applied with more force to the NEU, whose hostile stance has made thesuch an exhausting obstacle course. The militants cannot be allowed to prevail next week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum old baby yelled cant wake him up
story: The Brit, , discovered her four-month-old unconscious in the hotel room in Argyrades, Greece, as their holiday ended in tragedy. A nurse from England staying at the Labranda Sandy Beach Resort told of the heartbreaking battle to save him on Friday morning.She raced to the room to help after hearing the distraught mothers cries.The frontline nurse and the mums friend fought in vain for about  minutes to save the child.The locum nurse from Chippenham, Wiltshire, told Sun Online said: I did CPR with her friend.We heard help, help, phone the ambulance. Her friend was there doing CPR. We took over on the compressions, the two of us. title: indonesian tribe loved ones corpses cigarettes tradition
story: Shots of the Toraja Tribe, who live in South Sulawesi in Indonesia, capture villagers sprucing up their relatives in a bid to obtain good fortune.Images show a family lighting a cigarette hanging inside a corpse’s mouth, dressing skulls in bandanas and taking selfies with the dead bodies.There are around one million Torajan people in Indonesia, most of whom live in the South Sulawesi region. They believe that after death the soul remains in the house so the dead are treated to food, clothing, water, cigarettes.Bodies are kept wrapped in blankets in the room of the house or a ‘tongkonan’ - a traditional Torajan ancestral house with a distinctive boat-shaped roof so the rain water runs off.The fascinating snaps were captured by freelance photojournalist Hariandi Hafid show the Toraja tribe taking part in the “Manene” ritual - in which family members exhume and clean the bodies of the dead. Unlike in western cultures, where the body is swtly removed after death and frequently held a few days later, the tribe often keeps the bodies of their deceased loved ones in the family home for weeks,not months.During this time, the corpse will be spoken to in general conversation and a meal brought to the body three or four times a day.Once a funeral is held – after a suitable period of mourning and reflection – it is often a lavish affair costing exorbitant amounts of money and held over several days.The Toraja believe that death is just the next step in the soul’s journey through the universe. “My mother died suddenly, so we aren’t ready yet to let her go,” a Torajan woman, Yohana Palangda, told National Geographic in  of how this helps the grieving process.“I can’t accept burying her too quickly.”The ritual is performed during the harvest season around July, August and September and is typically performed every three or four years, depending on the familys wishes.During the procession, the traditional elderswill recite prayers in the ancient Toraja language.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: we need to return high street jane moore
story: Having sex was virtually impossible, because by the time we’d removed them we had fallen asleep with exhaustion.Now, jeans come in all shapes and sizes and — hallelujah — streeeeeeetch where necessary to accommodate our lumps and bumps.However, it’s imperative to try before you buyyou want to find the perfect pair and, thanks to lockdown, I found myself shopping for jeans, and other clothes — online.The results prove why we simply mustn’t allow our struggling High Street clothes shops to vanish without trace.I’m usually a size , but am now sporting a bread-baby after lock- down so decided to play safe by ordering a size bigger. Pictured is, apparently, a pair of “size ” jeans from online giant Asosin front of my old size sI couldn’t get them up one leg and, quite frankly, Kate Moss would struggle too. So they’re going back.Then a beguiling ad for summer dresses popped up on my Instagram account and I clicked through to a site called “Cinderear” showing a wide range of very pretty frocks on tanned and shapely models.I ordered what was described as a “Printed Folding Holiday Swing Dress” in what looked like an airy cotton, cinched in at the waist with a brown leather belt. The colour was described as apricot.What arrived — several weeks later — was a beyond-hideous sartorial aberration that was “Made in China” , out of a paper-thin polyester that would make me think twice about standing near a naked flame.What’s more, the colour was more camel and blue than “apricot”, it swamped me, and the brown belt in the photo was nowhere to be seen.It cost me  — approx £ — and the s policy is so ­unintelligible that it’s not worth the bother. More fool me.Buying a bookshelf or bog brush online is fine, but clothes is another matter. I like to feel the fabric and see the fit.So a couple of weeks ago, I masked up and ventured out on a shopping trip to West London’s vast Westfield where I felt like a ­Hollywood superstar having a ­personal shopping experience. It was am on a Monday morning and virtually empty.Little wonder when the ­government guidance says retailers must “discourage customers from handling products while browsing, and keep fitting rooms closed”.One store let me try on a dress then sanitised the cubicle afterwards, another told me thatI tried something on they would have to then take it off display for  hours.In LK Bennett, the fitting rooms were closed and I askedI could try on a blouse over my clothes, just to seeit actually fits. No, they said, you have to buy the item, take it home to try it on, then bring it backit doesn’t fit. Needless to say, I ed home empty-handed.So,our High Street clothes shops are to survive the pandemic, two things need to happen.Unless classed as vulnerable, those of us who actually enjoy clothes ­shopping need to get back out there as soon as possible and actively support them. And the Government needs to relax its strict rules and let retailers and shoppers take inidual responsibility for what happens in store.If I have to wear a mask and gloves to try on a pair of jeans in a cubicle, then I’m happy to do so. I’ll even wipe it down afterwards with my newly repurposed “apricot” dress.SPORTED by the likes of Chris Waddle back in the day, the mullet is apparently enjoying a resurgence during the pandemic.Oh dear. Now barbers have reopened, let’s hope the trend proves short-lived for the naff hairdo that was once described in a dictionary as: “Short at the front, long at the back and ridiculous all round.”FORMER Ukip leader Henry Bolton became embroiled in a scandal after leaving his third we for the charms of party supporter Jo Marney.Now, three years on, that relationship is also over. The reasons why are unclear, but Ms Marney, , says that aside from going on long walks and cosying up in country pubs, they “argued about the finer points of EU legislation”.Ah yes, that should do it.THE Duke and Duchess of Sussex will not feature in TV drama The Crown because there’s not “enough distance” from their story, says the show’s creator Peter Morgan.Also, their le is so outlandish that the series would fall under the category of reality show rather than drama.VINNIE JONES – the “hardman” of football – is seeing a psychologist three times a week after losing we Tanya to cancer.“I would recommend going to see a psychologist  per cent,” he says.“You’re not lying down on a couch asyou’re some lunatic or serial killer. Blokes don’t want to talk about it.“They’ll talk about the girl they slept with last night but won’t go and talk to a doctor about how they’re feeling.”He’s right, and with men accounting for  per cent of all suicides in the UK, it’s never been more important for men like Vinnie to convey that showing vulnerability isn’t a weakness – it’s an admirable strength.CLAUDIA SCHIFFER turned  on tuesday and says she has “never felt more confident or happy”.She adds that she embraces “now” and: “I don’t try to look or feel younger.”She doesn’t need to really, does she ELECTRIC car maker Tesla is developing a sensor that will detecta child has been left unattended in a hot car.Don’t we have those already They’re called parents.LIFE’S precious silences are few and far between. And when you’re PM, one can imagine they are practically non-existent.Particularly as, the ­second you step into the privacy of your own home, there’s a baby with no “on-off” switch.So Boris’s holiday tent – pitched a hundred yards away from his rented cottage on the Scottish coastline – intrigues me. Was it an escape for him alone to snatch a few hours of quiet reflection Or was it a chance for him and Carrie to have noisy sex away from the baby and ever-present bodyguards THE top dream jobs for school leavers are app or games developer and social media influencer.If kids don’t get back to school pronto, that’s all they’ll be able to do.NO ONE begrudges ­politicians a holiday – ­particularly during a ­parliamentary recess.But when you’re an Education minister, you have one job – to be around when the ordure inevitably hits the fan over A-level results being randomly downgraded by an algorithm.Yet not only did Gillian Keegan book a trip abroad, she actually posted a photo from the French Alps on results day – when countless students saw their future plans evaporate. Duh.She also decided to stay there after the quarantine rules came into force – meaning she will have to self-isolate at home for a fortnight on her .But hey ho she’s a taxpayer-funded civil servant so she’s comfortablein the knowledge that, unlike the self-employed, she won’t be losing any pay.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: defence sec slam labour pause veteran legislation
story: Ben Wallace branded it a “slap in the face to veterans” after his opposition shadow said new measures to protect troops breached human rights laws.The planned Overseas Operations Bill due before MPs next month enshrines a “statutory presumption against prosecution” after five years to all forces, including those who served in Iraq and Afghanistan.It has been drawn up to protect troops from vexatious complaints drummed up by tank chasing lawyers.But Labour’s John Healey said: “This clearly creates the risk that serious violations could go unpunishedan incident does not come to light for five years orinvestigations are drawn out beyond that deadline.”But Mr Wallace told The Sun: “Labours new found facade of supporting our armed forces has been exposed for what it is - fake.”He added: “Pausing the bill is a slap in the face to veterans who have gone through the turmoil of dealing with vexatious claims.”An MOD spokesperson said: “This vital piece of legislation will protect military personnel and veterans from vexatious claims and the cycle of re-investigation into alleged offences.“Pausing this bill will continue to leave our soldiers vulnerable to vexatious persecution. “The way to demonstrate support for our armed forces is to make progress with this important legislation.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tony abbott britain trade deal supremo
story: The forthright Aussie has been appointed joint President of Britain’s relaunched Board of Trade, tasked with drumming up deals for Britain around the world.It’s role is to “champion exports and inward and outward investment to deliver economic growth and prosperity” and has traditionally been made up of British political and business figures.But The Sun understands Boris Johnson has asked Mr Abbott to join as part of a drive to get a number of global “friends” to bang the drum from Brexit Britain.Mr Abbott led Australia from  to  and was a close ally to the UK during his premiership.He was also a vocal supporter of Brexit both before the referendum and ever since.Last year he made a plea to Brits not to worry about a No Deal exit from the EU, saying that Australia trades with the bloc on exactly those terms.He wrote: Let me reassure anyone in Britain, anxious about the prospect of no deal, that Australia does one hundred billion dollars’ worth of trade with the EU every single year, on this very basis.”Since then Mr Johnson and his ministers have attempted to rebrand a No Deal scenario as a “Australian-style deal”.Last night a Whitehall source said: “We are delighted to have him on board.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ofqual boss keep job cabinet office
story: The bungling bureaucrat walked the plank after wrecking exams day for hundreds of thousands of students.She decided to quit her £, a year job “by mutual agreement” with the Ofqual board.But The Sun understands she can still keep a lucrative post in the Cabinet Office despite the total shambles.A Cabinet Office spokesman said: Sally is a substantive civil servant and as such is able toto a job within the Civil Service.The Cabinet Office was unable to say what job Ms Collier might do, orshe would keep her eye-watering salary.The Department for Education was kept in the loop about the resignation talks, but did not demand her scalp, The Sun understands A source close to the discussions said: This has not been driven by the DFE demanding a head on platter.This is about the best way of taking Ofqual forward. There have been real dficulties this year and there will be a real job of putting it back together.Bosses from the schools watchdog Ofsted have been sent in to try to rescue the disaster-prone Ofqual.The under-fire boss was blasted for being “invisible” during the A Levels masking fiasco.Robert Halfon MP told Times Radio: Resignations are massive for the iniduals concerned.“Ive tried to stay away from finger wagging, because my policy is to find out whats gone wrong and who was responsible for it, and why this sort of mega-mess was allowed to happen in the first place.“Im not going to comment on iniduals, but clearly she felt Ofqual had failed the parents, pupils and schools, and thats why she went. No other Ofqual bosses are expected to resign at the moment.Former Ofqual chief regulator Dame Glenys Stacey is being brought back to steer the ship again.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said: “I welcome Ofqual’s announcement that Dame Glenys Stacey is to assume a temporary leadership role as acting Chief Regulator and also the new internal governance arrangements put in place with Ofsted support.“This will make sure Ofqual can fully focus on the important s it must deliver as the independent regulator for qualications, examinations and assessments in England.“Moving forward, my department will continue to work closely with Ofqual’s leadership to deliver fair results and exams for young people.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kids must wear face masks at school
story: The screeching U-turn came just  hours after No ruled out making them compulsory for pupils.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesFurious Tories branded Education Secretary Mr Williamson’s department the “department of mess-ups”.Ministers said face coverings would have to be worn by England’s secondary school children in areas of “high Covid transmission”.These are any with a form of local lockdown, currently including large swathes of the North West.Pupils will have to wear masks in communal areas of schools such as hallways — but not classrooms.In the rest of the country, it will be up to secondary heads.The announcement is the fourth humiliating U-turn by the department in two months. And it is another blow to Mr Williamson’s shattered reputation.One furious Tory MP told The Sun: “My God, what a bloody shambles. You cannot make these changes five minutes before schools reopen. It is yet another mess- up by this department of mess-ups.” Gavin Williamson’s team had already back-tracked on the A-levels marking fiasco, free school meals, and a promise to get all primary school pupils back to school by July.Downing Street had spent months furiously batting off calls by some unions to roll out masks in schools.No caved after Scotland declared them compulsory and heads said they would be introduced regardless.Government sources said they changed their mind after new World Health Organisation guidance said over-s should wear masks.And they suggested it would help convince hardline unions to agree to schools ing next week.BORIS Johnson has been on a mission to persuade parents it is safe to send kids to school.“The risk of Covid is small and it is far more damaging for a child to be away from school any longer,” he said.But the PM has now changed his mind and says kids will have to wear face masks. Not so safe, then.Talk about mixed messages.  GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: schools england masks visors boris
story: The PM suggested that a u-turn was on the cards just hours after Scotland ordered kids to wear them at school from Monday.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesTES reported that the Government is expected to make a major u-turn this afternoon - saying that masks will be worn by kids at school in communal areas.It reported that Public Health England and the DFE have signed off the move.Department for Education sources did not deny the story today.Earlier in the day Mr Johnson said the Government would always review the evidence and the advice may change.On a business visit today he told reporters: On the issue of whether or not to wear masks in some contexts - you know, well look at the the changing medical evidence as we go on.If we need to change the advice then of course we will.It comes  hours after No insisted that the Government would not be launching a fresh review after the World Health Organisation said all kids over  should wear them.Asked why the UK Government was ignoring the WHO, Mr Johnson said this lunchtime: The overwhelming priority is to get all pupils into school.If there are things we have to do to y the advice on medical grounds, we will, of course, do that.But as the chief medical officer, all our scientic advisers, have said, schools are safe.Meanwhile schools started to announce their own policies on face masks - piling pressure on the PM to change tack.The Oasis Academy chain of  schools today joined several others in saying that their pupils would have to wear masks in corridors and other communal areas to stop the spread of the virus when schoolsnext week.The chains founder, Steve Chalke, said this morning: Oasis has booked face visors  masks for all our school staff  masksfor our secondary students for transition in corridors etc.It came as Scotland confirmed that school pupils will have to wear face coverings in corridors and communal areas from next Monday.Any kids over the age of  will have to wear them on school transport from Monday too, it was confirmed today.And kids could even have to wear them in the classrooms tootheres a local outbreak -public health officials force it of the school thinks its necessary.Ms Sturgeon said today she thought it was the right thing to do.But there will be no fines for not sticking to the rules, the First Minister stressed.The Welsh Government are also set to review their evidence on face coverings in schools too.Boris Johnson is to give an online press-conference style event in the next few days to try and allay fears about theto school.No opened up the floor for questions about coronavirus online today.The Governments advice as of May , which is based on information from SAGE says: Face coverings do not need to be worn in schools.And Business SecretaryAlok Sharma said today: Throughout this process we have followed the scientists and medical advice. PHE doesn’t currently recommend face coverings in schools. The reason is pupils and staff mix in consistent groups.We are always considering the latest advice and evidence.Headteachers are today calling on the Government to review their face masks advice ahead of schools .The Association of School and College leaders said today there was a lack of clarity on the issue.And Director of Public Health for Gateshead, Alice Wiseman, said she wouldreview the issue with local heads.It is my intention to have a broad discussion with teachers in Gateshead to see what would work best for them and their parents, she told Radio  today.We need to make sure they are not used as an alternative for the most effective prevention measure, such as social distancing.Former Education Secretary Justine Greening said this morning the Government should at least consider the matter.She told the BBC: It is something ministers and gov should consider.It just seems a sensible potential step that should be looked at.It is one of the things that can be considered to not only put confidence back into a system that badly needs it but to be another step that can help reduce risks.Scottish and Northern Irish schools have already gone back, and pupils in England willto classrooms from next week.But yesterday the Government insisted that it would not look again at face masks for kids in schools - despite a World Health Organisation recommendation that over s should wear them.No insisted that masks in schools would harm kids learning - and there were no plans to look again at the advice.Gavin Williamson slapped down Nicola Sturgeons demands for coverings - and said there was no evidence children should have to wear masks on top of the social distancing policies that are going to be in place.Children are placed in social bubbles of their classes and have to stay m away from their teachers when theyto the classroom.Mr Williamson said last night: Were not in a position where we are suggesting [masks for schoolchildren] because we think there is a system of controls, that are in place in all schools, for children to be able tosafely and for staff to be able tosafely.At the moment kids under the age of  dont have to wear them at all across the UK.But those over  have to wear them like adults do in shops and on public transport.At the moment its up to inidual schools and headsthey want to enforce mask-wearing - with a handful choosing to do so.Ms Sturgeon has said kids can wear them in classroomsthey want to.She told the daily coronavirus briefing yesterday: Were consulting on this specic measure because, firstly, mixing between dferent groups is more likely in corridors and communal areas - increasing the potential for transmission.Secondly, crowding and close contact in these areas is more likely and voices could be raised, resulting in greater potential for creating aerosol transmission.Finally, theres also less scope for ventilation in these areas.A Number  spokesman said: There are no plans to review the guidance on face coverings in schools.We are conscious of the fact that it would obstruct communication between teachers and pupils.I dont think the WHO guidance refers specically to whether a child over  should wear a mask in school.The Department of Education said that masks were not necessary as other measures were in place - such as bubbles and extra cleaning.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pubs could be ordered to shut birmingham
story: The City Council today revealed tough new powers to try and stop the city from going into a full lockdown.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt means police will be able to stop people going in restaurants or bars which arent covid-secure.And some large events such as weddings and funerals could be cancelled too.Cops will also have the power to shutdown raves at outdoor spaces too.The measures are partly to stop the spread of the virus so that schools dont have to shut and kids education wont be harmed any further, leaders said today.It comes after a Gold Command meeting with Matt Hancock and local leaders in Birmingham last week.The city became an area of concern and will now become an area of enhanced support after a spike in cases.However, sources in Birmingham told The Sun today that rates of infection have been going down over recent days and the panic in government is starting to calm.Last week it was reported that cases had reached  per , in the last week. This compared to Oldham - which is under tighter lockdown rules - and had a high of  per , earlier this month.Last week they were told not to meet ANYONE outside their household to stop the bug spreading further.However, local leaders are still mulling whether to slap on extra restrictions on Birmingham residentsthe numbers dont go the right way.West Midlands Mayor Andy Street said today: Given the illegal raves and some premises not complying with track and trace, this tightening of powers is the right move.However talks with Government are still ongoing, andwe want to avoid new restrictions we need everyone to stick to the rules.The news also comes as cops broke up SEVENTY illegal parties in Brum last weekend despite the threat of tighter measures, and the raves are thought to be a contributing factor to the ongoing case numbers.Younger people and people going out to work are forming the bulk of new cases in the city.But police across the UK will have the power to slap ravers with £, fines for hosting illegal parties from this week.Councillor Ian Ward, Leader of Birmingham City Council said today: “While the recent figures show our rates are going down, we cannot be complacent.We must all continue to follow all the relevant safety guidance in order to protect our families, friends and work colleagues. Most importantly staying disciplined now is a price worth paying when compared to the cost of damaging the future le chances of our City’s children – which may happenthere is a spike in the rate of infections and schools have to close, or parents do not send them due to concerns about the potential risks . Whilst the impact of Covid- may be felt over the next few years, the negative impacts upon children not being present at school will last a letime.The new powers mean cops will be able to intervene to keep citizens safe and stop them from spreading the infection.Members of the public can let the council or police aware of any concerns they have by ringing a special hotline or filling in a form online.Offending businesses will be issued with written warnings and served with a closure of noticethey refuse to comply.The current rules for pubs and other hospitality venues include:Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsopinionKey worker heroes saved the country - now lets give them the power to rebuild itThey have risen to this unprecedented challenge and put their lives on the line to keep our country goingShareCommentsByAngela Rayner:,  AUG NewsopinionKey workers are ideally placed to rebuild our communities and our country " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOur key worker heroes have been on the frontline working round the clock to get us through this crisis. They have risen to this unprecedented challenge and put their lives on the line to keep our country going. Now we need them to help lead the recovery from this crisis as we build back better. NHS and social workers, bus drivers, posties, delivery drivers, shop workers, and so many others have made sure we have all been cared for, fed and connected during this pandemic. They are ideally suited to rebuilding our communities and our country. They are ideally suited to rebuilding our communities and our country in the months and years ahead. The last few months have proven beyond all doubt that it is the unsung, underpaid and undervalued workers who are the backbones of our communities – the people that our economy and our country cannotwithout. They know what their communities need and truly know what it means to be a ‘public servant’. We want to ensure that our key workers are at the heart of decision-making across the country, which is why we are encouraging and supporting those who want to get involved in politics and stand for election in the years ahead. Politics is not arcane parliamentary language of Statutory Instruments or Select Committees. Politics is about what is happening on your high street, in your town, at your workplace. Politics is about making sure your children’s school has got the resources it needs or fighting back against dodgy landlords ripping off tenants. Real people and real lives. It is clear for all to see that our political institutions do not reflect the communities that they serve. I am proud that before I became a Member of Parliament I worked in our social care sector, going from house to house in my community supporting those who needed help. But when MPs talk in the House of Commons about the crisis facing our social care sector, how many of them have worked on the frontline and have first-hand experience of it  During debates on the Budget or the economy how many MPs have fed their families on a minimum wage pay packet  Not many, and certainly not nearly enough. This needs to change, and I am determined that the Labour Party, working with our trade unions and colleagues in local government, will lead that change.  I am proud that the Parliamentary Labour Party is the most erse it has ever been and is more than half of Labour MPs are women for the first time in our history. But we all know there is a huge amount of work to do, at all levels of government. We need to do more to ensure that our political institutions and elected representatives are rooted in our communities and better represent and reflect our communities, in all of their ersity. As deputy leader and party chair I am leading initiatives to encourage and support more female, black, Asian and minority ethnic, disabled and LGBTQ+ members to put themselves forward to stand as candidates and run for office. Now our Party and our movement will also be working to identy and support key workers who want to champion their community.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA firm run by a close ally of Dominic Cummings was awarded a £, contract to advise Ofqual ahead of the A-level results fiasco. It was reported last week that Public First had been hired to help the exam regulator with insight on public opinion for this yearaposs exam arrangements. The Mirror can today reveal the cost to the public for the first time, after the Government quietly published contracts on Sunday. Newly published details also confirm the deal was put in place without other firms being allowed to bid for the work. This latest revelation takes the total value of contracts handed to Public First this year over £ million.Public First is a small lobbying and research firm run by James Frayne, a Brexit ally of Mr Cummings, and Rachel Wolf, who co-wrote the  Tory manesto.The publication of the new contract was revealed by Tussell, a database of public contracts and spend. It had already been reported the firm had been awarded an £,, no-competition contract to research public opinion on government policies - including Brexit and the coronavirus pandemic.The Mirror revealed last week that the firm were given another £, by the Department of Health and Social Careto identy ways to lock in the lessons learned by the Government during the Covid- crisis. When the existence of the Ofqual contract was first revealed in thelast week, the regulator said the usual tendering rules had been bypassed because of “exceptional circumstances”. Government contracts are usually awarded after a tender process which allows multiple providers to compete to provide the best value. But after the Covid- pandemic struck, new rules allowed contracts worth hundreds of thousands of pounds to be handed to firms directlythey were deemed “urgent”. A spokesperson said: “Due to the exceptional circumstances presented by the cancellation of exams, the single tender justication process was used for this contract, due to the need to urgently procure the work, in line with our procurement policy.”Public First founder James Frayne and Boris Johnson ’s top aide Dominic Cummings worked together at the Department for Education while Michael Gove was Education Secretary.Years earlier in , Mr Frayne and Mr Cummings founded an anti-EU think tank together, called the New Frontiers Foundation. story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Lockdown legacy could be backlog of suffering of cancer patientsWe cannot allow the legacy of lockdown to be thousands of lives lost to other diseases. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAdrian Rogers is one of the forgotten casualties of the coronavirus crisis. The scaffolding supervisor has terminal cancer after a potentially le-saving operation was cancelled because of Covid. Our hearts go out to Adrian and his family. What makes this all the more unbearable is it will not be an isolated case. Cancer Research fears a third of cancer patients have missed vital treatment because of the pandemic. The number of urgent cancer referrals by GPs in England fell by a half in May and there are more than two million people waiting for breast, bowel and cervical cancer screenings. We cannot allow the legacy of lockdown to be thousands of lives lost to other diseases. The same spirit of endeavour which saw the building of the Nightingale hospitals should now be applied to clearing this backlog and restoring all NHS services. Lives depend on it. Your turn Gav OFQUAL chief Sally Collier today put Gavin Williamson to shame by resigning over the exams fiasco. In a more honourable world it would be the Education Secretary who handed in his notice. Yet can again we are seeing civil servants being made scapegoats for failings by arrogant and incompetent Conservative ministers. Mr Williamson has been promoted way beyond his ability. Not only has he presided over the exam grading fiasco he has failed to set out a clear plan for schools to reopen. The confusion over whether pupils should wear face coverings has added to the chaos. At the same time figures show the gap between the richest and poorest pupils is rising. If Boris Johnson really cared about children’s schooling he would install a new Education Secretary capable of sorting out this mess. It’s Santatiser!

story: NewsBritish tanks may be mothballed in bold move to boost cyber warfare capabilitiesSome of Britains Challenger tanks may be mothballed as the Ministry of Defence looks for ways to invest in cyber security as it faces cuts to its overall budgetShareCommentsByChris HughesDefence and Security Editor:,  AUG NewsChallenger tanks may be mothballed as part of cost-cutting efforts " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDefence bosses are considering mothballing a number of Challenger tanks as part of radical cost-cutting. The proposal would free up millions of pounds to boost cyber warfare capability amid threats from Russia, China and Iran. One option being considered by the Ministry of Defence is to scrap plans to upgrade much of the fleet of Challenger  tanks and Warrior armoured fighting vehicles. A defence source told the Mirror “pressures on budgets across the department” led bosses to come up with the potential changes. The insider added: “But it would be a very big and bold decision, especially as the Warrior fighting vehicles have proved useful in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. No decision has been made as yet on the future of the Challenger and it is extremely unlikely it would be mothballed entirely. There is a chance some may be mothballed.” The MoD is under pressure to invest in cyber defence even though overall budgets are set to be slashed due to the economic downturn. Despite cuts, Britain is also committed to making a signicant contribution to NATO and helping defend Europe against the threat from Russia. The source added: “Having Challenger has been a huge plus in ensuring our partners know the UK is making a sizeable contribution to NATO.” The insider said the Army is “already very stretched”. If the Challenger tanks were mothballed they would be kept in storage and made available in an emergency.

story: NewsCoronavirus lockdown sparks revival of family businesses as owners employ relativesResearch among  small business owners found that nearly a quarter had recently taken on a family member to help out during the coronavirus lockdownShareCommentsByAlice Hughes:,  AUG NewsThe research, commissioned by Funding Circle, found the family employment typically lasted seven weeks " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailLockdown has sparked a revival of the traditional family business as an increasing number of owners employ relatives, according to a study. Research among  small business owners found that nearly a quarter had recently taken on a family member. Of those, % had hired their partner,  per cent recruited a sibling and one in  had even sought help from their in-laws. Almost half employed relatives during lockdown because they needed extra help, while % felt their loved ones had the skills they were looking for. Other reasons included their family member wanting to gain work experience or because they were struggling to find work after finishing education during the pandemic. The research, commissioned by Funding Circle, found the family employment typically lasted seven weeks, but % still have their relative working for them now.Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog hereAnd while % are considering taking them on full time following this experience, % would look at hiring more relatives in the future. It also emerged that as a result of this, more than a fth would like to see more traditional family businesses making a comeback. Lisa Jacobs, Funding Circleaposs UK managing director, said: Family sits at the heart of many successful small businesses. One of the silver linings of this crisis might be a revival of the traditional family business, with relatives spending more time together as business colleagues and partners as well as at home. The research also found more than a third of small business owners admitted their relative worked harder than they expected them to. More than a quarter said their relative’s working attitude was respectful and % said they seemed enthusiastic. Similarly, % of owners said working with their relation was fun and %felt it was motivating, yet % described it as dficult at times.  And although  % of those polled said taking on their loved one was positive for their family relationship, three in  struggled to be ‘boss’ to them. When it came to family perks, % of bosses admitted they gave their family member flexible hours, %offered longer breaks and %even gave them a free lunch. The findings come after a separate study of , relatives of small business owners found that of the % who were taken on by their family, a third found it motivating. Popular family businesses were found to fall into the sectors of retail, business, consulting and management, and creative arts and design. And for % of ‘employees’ the new role with their relative was something completely dferent to their usual job. For a fth, their new ‘boss’ was their dad, while a tenth had their mum to answer to and %  were ‘hired’ by their uncle. More than a third even said the experience has made them want to be more involved with the family business and % feel encouraged to start their own company. But % admitted they now realise how much work goes into running a business, according to the OnePoll figures. More than a quarter found themselves helping out a relative because they were on furlough, while % had always had an interest in it and now had the time. Positives of working for a family member included being able to act completely themselves , spending more time with familyand feeling less pressure .

story: NewsMum diagnosed with  tumours after Specsavers eye test shows off DIY home transformationEXCLUSIVE: Sharon Coupe was diagnosed with stage four bowel cancer following a routine eye test but says there’s no need to let things go just because of cancer’ and has completed an inspiring DIY makeover on her homeShareCommentsByTfany WallisJoseph WilkesReporter:,  AUG NewsSharon Coupe was diagnosed with cancer in May  after an eye test " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mother who was diagnosed with cancer after a routine eye check at Specsavers has revealed her stunning DIY home transformation. Sharon Coupe, , from Edwinstowe near Sherwood Forest has always been house proud but felt like she stopped caring about her home after her diagnosis in May . The mother-of-two’s best friend was determined to help her with a DIY makeover and the two of them have spent lockdown making her home beautul again. Sharon, who has stage four bowel cancer and five tumours, said she believes there is no need to let things go just because of having cancer. She said: My house has always been beautul, but when I got diagnosed I just felt like I didn’t care what the house looked like anymore. If I was to die, nobody would say aposoh she had a lovely houseapos. But Cathie has dragged me out of my rut. We are now steadily going through the house and making it beautul again. In May , Sharon was rushed to Kings Mill Hospital in Nottinghamshire the same day as having her eyes tested after the optician saw something behind her eye that was illuminating. She was referred as an ‘urgent casualty’ before being told she would need to go to Hallamshire hospital in Sheffield. Two weeks later, the support worker was told she had a tumour behind her eye and needed to undergo a ciliary flap biopsy - she had the procedure on th August . One week later, doctors confirmed the cancerous tumour behind her right eye as secondary. Sharon, who is mother to Connor, , and Aaron, , then underwent a series of tests to find the primary cancer. Sharon said:I asked the doctors not to sugar coat anything for me. But my heart sank - I had silent tears rolling down my face and all I could think of was my boys Connor and Aaron. I bought them up alone as when Connor was five, his dad and I separated but I found out I was nine weeks pregnant with Aaron. My boys are my absolute rocks.  I provided a -hour urine sample, had numerous head, shoulder and full body scans before being sent to the Western Park hospital. I also had two liver biopsies and had to stay in hospital for five nights. The results delivered the devastating news that the primary cancer was in Sharon’s bowel - but it had also spread to her liver, lungs, right eye and bones - finding five tumours in total. She was told it is an extremely rare cancer which is inoperable and incurable but hopefully treatable. Her best friend Cathie and her mother were both by Sharon’s side as the results were given to her. Sharon added: Once the professor said the primary was in my lower bowel, I askedit could be removed but he said “that’s not all” as he explained the five tumours.  The professor said in his  years of experience - he had only seen three patients with this rare cancer - Sharon being his third. Sharon hasn’t been given a timeline but says she is now stage four. In July, she underwent an MRI scan and more PET scans. The last ones had shown treatment had been successful as  of the  tumours are stable. However the tumour behind her eye is not stable - and it has grown, with a cataract over it. She recently found out that the characteristics of the tumour had changed indicating it could have spread to her brain.  She said: As for the eye - I have now been told regardlessit’s gone into my brain I have to have the eye removed as the tumour is pushing on the retina. The cancer has also spread to my skull, collar bones, manubrium, my hips, my pelvis, my spine and three disks. The results of these new scans can show even more but we have to wait and see. The-mother-of-two felt like she stopped caring about her home after she was diagnosed - despite previously being described as ‘house proud’. But the best friends have now been completing a DIY home makeover. Sharon believes there is no need to let things go just because of cancer but said she has noticed DIY work taking a lot longer due to the fatigue that comes with the disease.  She said: There’s no need at all to let things go just because you have cancer… Yes it’s taking a lot longer to do as the fatigue that comes with this disease is something you cannot describe. But we are doing this and we are getting there! We are doing one room at a time but it takes a while as I do all the wallpaper, I am up and down the ladders, Cathie has been painting and I’ve glossed all the doors.Sharon experiences horrendous fatigue and extreme side effects from treatments including hot flushes, temperature, sweating, aching and headaches.She has also had pain in her hips and lower back throughout the DIY work.  Sharon has morphine inside her   and believes she wouldnapost be able to she didn’t have the constant pain relief. Sharon is on sandostatin LAR which is injected into her buttocks muscle every three weeks. She also has an injection in her stomach every eight weeks for her bone cancer but now suffers from extremely sensitive teeth. She added: I have Calci D mg a day, docusate and senna to help with the bowel, Creon  to help with my stomach and oxy norm every  hours for pain. I am on antidepressants too as the professor said as strong as I am and as much as I am smiling whenever they see me, he thinks this will take its toll.  He said it is a lot for any one person to put up with and I now have counselling too. However the pains and medication hasn’t stopped Sharon. The best friends have been working through the house transforming one room at a time. Sharon’s bedroom cost £ and is now complete with flamingo wallpaper and pink bedding and curtains. Her bedroom took three months to complete as Sharon struggled to do the wallpapering and go up and down ladders.  The friends then moved onto another bedroom which Sharon wanted to make grey, black and silver. This was done during lockdown and took five weeks. Sharon and Cathie worked on the bedroom with the help of her two sons and a family friend Les - the transformation cost £. She said: I think the room looks so classy now. All of these rooms have been done during lockdown. I can honestly say I am loving doing all of this. It may take its toll by the end of the day and it may take longer but when it’s done the feeling I get is of great joy knowing I’ve made an effort and not just stayed in bed feeling sorry for myself all day.  Sharon has also been keeping her friends and family updated via social media and said she has been overwhelmed by the support and generosity of people. She has had ’s of cards, flowers, gts and hampers and feels there are so many people that have gone out of their way and above and beyond to support her.The mother said she gets kind messages everyday from people asking hershe needs help and said she had no idea people on Facebook were so kind and caring.However Sharon recently experienced a breakdown and her two sons surprised her by taking her to the garden. Connor and Aaron surprised their mum by pulling all the weeds up, turfing the lawn and creating a decking area with a patio for her. Her friend Cathie also planted lots of flowers and even got Sharon a sunlounger to cheer her up. She said: Connor and Aaron came to my room after three weeks of breaking down and said aposright come on mum - let’s get you up.apos They took me to my dump of a back garden and when they said open your eyes - I was amazed! My garden was beautul and it really did help and prompted me to get up and sort myself out. Sadly money hasn’t been easy for Sharon as she only qualied for statutory sick pay - having not been in her job long enough.

Mercy Baguma, from Uganda, was found dead by police on Saturday August  after friends raised the alarm when she had not been heard from since Tuesday. The baby boy was rushed to hospital for treatment and is now being cared for by his father, reports GlasgowLive. Mercy - who was an asylum seeker - lost her job after her limited leave to remain had reportedly expired, meaning she was no longer allowed to work. Mercy, , and her son were believed to have been relying on food from friends and charities. The Home Office has promised to carry out a full investigation into her case. Robina Qureshi, Director of Positive Action in Housing said: “This is the third tragedy to affect the city’s refugee population in as many months. Mercy contacted our charity on August  and said she was not getting any financial support yet had made an application to MigrantHelp. Had she lived she would have been a high priority for a crisis payment from our Emergency Relief Fund like hundreds of others left ally destitute by the asylum system. “The question remains, why are mothers and babies being left to go hungry in this city, why is it being left to charities and volunteers to pick up the pieces  Does society have anything to say about that other than call them a drain on society  The fact is there is no safety netyouaposre a refugee or migrant. You are left destitute and without resources. And youaposre left silenced by far right rhetoric for being forced to ask for help. Marno Botha and his girlfriend Caitlynn Van Hecke thought it would be a laugh to change the colour of his facial hair from blond to black - with Marno saying he would just shave it offit went wrong. story: NewsScientist who revealed worlds icecaps are melting is killed by climate changeGlaciologist Konrad Steffen, , was working near the Swiss Camp research station he set up  years ago when he plunged into a crevasse created by rising temperatures in the ArcticShareCommentsByNada FarhoudEnvironment editor:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsKonrad Steffen plunged into the crevasse " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe expert who alerted the world to Greenland’s disappearing ice sheet has died after plunging into a crevasse created by rising temperatures in the Arctic. Glaciologist Konrad Steffen, , was working near the Swiss Camp research station he set up  years ago when the accident happened in poor visibility. He drowned in deep meltwater at the foot of the crevasse. Ryan Neely, a University of Leeds climate scientist who studied under Dr Steffen, said crevasses in the area “were unheard-of” until recently. He said: “It looks like climate change actually claimed him as a victim.”  When Steffen, from Switzerland, first arrived in Greenland in  to set up a weather station, rising sea levels were not a huge concern, although the scientic community had agreed climate change was under way.But this changed after Steffen proved that not only were the ice sheets melting, but they were also moving and breaking up into the sea. He has yet to be proved wrong. Known as “Koni”, he set up Swiss Camp on the western edge of the ice sheet and with a growing number of colleagues and students, would set out for weather stations every morning on a snowmobile, equipped with a satellite phone, an emergency sleeping bag, and a packet of Marlboros. He only slept four hours a night, and kept going by drinking espresso after espresso. Colleague Jason Box, a climate scientist, once said: “There has been speculation among us that he isn’t actually human. Some of his students believe he has espresso running through his veins.” Dr Neely remembered once waking up in his bunk, only to hear Dr Steffen ask: “How long do you think it would take for the entire Greenland ice sheet to melt ” He had been up for hours, making back-of-the envelope calculations.  He realised the melting ice was becoming a threat which world leaders should wake up to, and former US Vice President Al Gore and Nancy Pelosi, speaker of the House of Representatives, were among the politicians who visited the camp in Greenland. In , Steffen flew over the Jakobshavn Glacier and saw that its tongue had collapsed, as though “somebody had hit it with a massive hammer”. Seismographs began to pick up an increasing number of ice quakes, suggesting the ice sheet was juddering towards the sea. The temperature was rising so steeply that at first Steffen did not believe his own monitors. After  years, they indicated a rise of C. Zurich-born Steffen believed the scientic community’s predictions of sea level rise were too optimistic. In , after the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change predicted sea levels would rise by cm to cm by , Steffen said: “Unfortunately, I think we are looking more like a metre.” He told a journalist: “There will be a change coming, and obviously a change that we have not seen in thousands of years.” Because of the decline of sun-reflecting sea ice, the Arctic is thought to be warming twice as fast as the rest of the world.
